title: BHP revs up green push at Chilean copper mines
text:
Social value is the company's term for its proactive embrace of the decarbonisation agenda and the expansion of climate-related activities into its supply chain and into the communities in which it operates.

"It delivers the dual objective we usually talk about: it's good for the environment, good in terms of carbon emissions, but it's also great business for us ... in terms of the security of supply, with a lot more commercial flexibility and a significant energy price reduction," Mr Malchuk said.

"This is what we mean when we talk about financial and social value being codependent."

This contracts would cut "scope 2" emissions at the two mines to almost zero, he said, displacing up to 3 million tonnes of carbon dioxide compared with the fossil fuel contract that they are replacing.

Sustainable copper, green copper is an imperative for the industry. We need to demonstrate our green credentials. — BHP Minerals America president Daniel Malchuk

"Just to give you an idea of the magnitude of this, it's equivalent to the annual emissions of approximately 700,000 cars," he said.

"Sustainable copper, green copper ... is an imperative for the industry. We need to continue to demonstrate our green credentials."

Chile is responsible for about a third of global copper production, and BHP produces about a quarter of the country's output.

BHP also used its announcement to update its progress towards its 2030 target for eliminating water drawdown from aquifers at the mines, which are located in the Atacama Desert, one of the driest places on earth.

A new desalination water plant will come online at Spence in 2020, which will allow desalinated water to become the mine's primary source. The plan will have a capacity of 1000 litres a second, and will support the Spence mine's "Growth Option" expansion.

Desalination upgrades at Escondida will increase capacity there, with BHP saying it had invested $US4 billion in Escondida's desalination projects so far.

BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie said last Thursday that desalination might also be an option at Olympic Dam, assuming the site reached a scale equivalent to the Chilean operations.

He also said copper was set to become one of BHP's most promising businesses, given the likely surge in demand associated with accelerating decarbonisation and the shift to copper-intensive renewable energy sources.

BHP is exploring greenfield copper opportunities in Ecuador. Mr Malchuk said a greenfield project in Chile would have to use renewable energy and desalinated water from day one, but in Ecuador it was "too early to tell".
description: All power at the Escondida and Spence mines will come from renewables, and no water will come from aquifers.
